mistral.reason: The Dirham was a type of silver coin used throughout the different Caliphates of early Islam, but not all coins minted during the Umayyad Caliphate were dirhams. Other types of coins such as dinars and dirham-dinars were also minted during this period. Therefore, stating that the currency of the Umayyad Caliphate is only Dirham is incorrect.

gemma2.reason: The provided text explicitly states that the dirham was a type of silver coin used throughout the different Caliphates of early Islam, and specifically mentions an Umayyad dirham minted in Iraq during the rule of the Umayyad Caliphate.

llama3.1.reason: The Umayyad Caliphate's official currency was the Dinar, not the Dirham.

qwen2.5.reason: The context mentions that the dirham was a type of silver coin used throughout the different Caliphates of early Islam, including during the Umayyad Caliphate. Therefore, it is accurate to say that the currency of the Umayyad Caliphate included dirhams.
